title: Overview of Bone Health
content: Bone health is an important topic for everyone, from children to the elderly. Bone mineral density, how it’s measured, how it changes over the course of life, and the variability between sexes largely due to changes in estrogen levels are all crucial aspects of bone health. There are ways that one can improve bone health, from exercise to nutrition supplements to drugs. It's also important to understand what happens when one may be forced to be sedentary (e.g., bedrest) and how you can work to minimize the damage during these periods.

title: Bone Mineral Density
content: Bone mineral density (BMD) is a measure of the amount of minerals, such as calcium, in your bones. This measurement can help determine the strength of your bones and your risk for developing osteoporosis. BMD changes throughout life and differs between men and women, largely due to changes in estrogen levels. It's important to have your BMD measured, especially as you age, to monitor your bone health.

title: Impact of Estrogen Levels on Bone Health
content: Changes in estrogen levels, such as during menopause, can impact bone health. Hormone replacement therapy (HRT) is not considered a standard of care for postmenopausal bone loss. There are other factors that may determine who may be at higher risk of poor bone health.

title: Drugs and Bone Health
content: Certain common drugs can negatively impact bone mineral density. There are also pharmaceutical drugs prescribed for those with low BMD.

title: Physical Activity and Bone Health
content: Certain types of physical activity can positively impact bone health. However, weight loss can negatively impact bone health, but exercise can counteract those effects.

title: Nutrition and Supplements for Bone Health
content: Nutrition and supplements play a crucial role in maintaining and improving bone health.

title: Impact of Sedentary Periods on Bone Health
content: Extreme sedentary periods, such as bedrest, can have a negative impact on bone health. There are ways to minimize their damage to bone.

title: Accidental Deaths and Causes
content: For people younger than 60, overdoses are the predominant cause of accidental death. For people over 65, falling is the primary cause. By the time you’re 75, the risk of death from a fall is enormous. It’s not as high as Alzheimer’s disease, cancer, or heart disease, but it comes in pretty much just after that.

title: Preventing Accidental Deaths
content: You can’t wait until you’re in that bucket to decide you’re going to do something about it. Just as for atherosclerosis, we don’t want to wait until we’ve had our first heart attack. In the same way, you don’t want to wait until you have osteopenia or osteoporosis and you’re 60 years old to say, it’s time to do something about this.

title: Mortality Following Hip Fracture
content: Fractures that end lives tend to be hip fractures first, followed by pelvic fractures. If you’re a man that is 90 years old or above and you have a hip fracture, more than 40% of you will be dead within a year. For people over the age of 80, your mortality is in the neighborhood of a third within a year after a hip fracture.

title: Defining Osteopenia and Osteoporosis
content: Osteopenia and osteoporosis just exists on a continuum relative to healthy bone. When you go from healthy bone to osteopenia, that represents about a 10% reduction in bone mineral density relative to a young healthy adult. Osteoporosis is a further degradation where you hit about 25% reduction.

title: Measuring Bone Mineral Density
content: DEXA is a super, super low radiation scan, nothing like a CT scan. Takes 10 minutes, you lay on a table, a little scanner moves over your body, and it’s using two very low dose X-rays that are absorbed differentially by bones and soft tissues, so it’s able to differentiate between adipose tissue, bone and lean tissue, or non-adipose tissue.

title: Interpreting DEXA Scores
content: The number you’re going to get is not typically going to be reported in grams per centimeter cubed for your BMD because that information is not that helpful. What you really need to know is statistically, where do you rank? This is done via T-score (comparing you to a young, healthy adult); and a Z-score (comparing you to an adult that is your age).

title: Bone Mineral Density Variability
content: Women are disproportionately affected by estrogen withdrawal, which can lead to a decrease in bone mineral density (BMD). BMD varies between sexes and races, with non-Hispanic Black individuals having a higher BMD for both men and women than non-Hispanic White, which has a higher BMD than Mexican-American. However, race is not typically factored into risk assessment for osteoporosis.

title: Bone Mineral Density Scan Recommendations
content: The typical recommendation is for high risk people to be 50, but typically 65 is when they want to start screening women, and for men it’s typically 70. For someone who is at serious risk of osteoporosis, which includes men and women over the age of 50, we can adjust those and come down a little bit. The WHO is a little bit more aggressive and recommends screening women by the age of 40.

title: Bone Mineral Density Changes Throughout Life
content: Most of the growth in the length of a bone and the size of the bone is happening during childhood and adolescence. That’s also when you’re really accumulating the bulk of BMD. For instance, between about the ages of about 8 and 20, BMD was doubling. BMD will actually potentially improve up to about the age of 30. It can stay quite flat, in both sexes, until you’re about 40 or 50, and then bone loss effectively sinks in.

title: Impact of Estrogen Levels on Bone Health
content: The signaling process to deposit more bone tissue is regulated very heavily by estrogen. In the absence of estrogen, that signal gets reduced and that’s effectively why menopause, which is a sudden withdrawal of estrogen, is such a devastating thing for women who don’t have their hormones replaced. And that’s why BMD loss is significant in the postmenopausal woman. Men are also losing estrogen as they age, but at a far more gradual rate than women, making them at greater risk for osteopenia and osteoporosis.

title: Hormone Replacement Therapy for Postmenopausal Bone Loss
content: HRT is not considered standard of care for postmenopausal bone loss. However, studies have shown that HRT can decrease fracture risk. The risk of breast cancer and cardiovascular disease from hormone replacement therapy is virtually nonexistent, especially with the adoption of topical forms of estradiol, as opposed to oral forms.

title: Risk Factors for Poor Bone Health
content: Family history and genetics account for up to 50% of bone health. Having either parent that’s had a history of a hip fracture is a huge red flag. Other factors include fractures related to mild or moderate trauma, and poor nutritional state in female athletes, which can lead to a very low BMI, low body fat percent, and eventually estrogen deficiency.

title: Female Athlete Triad
content: Interrelated conditions of low bone health, hormone dysfunction, and low BMI are collectively known as the female athlete triad. Low BMI in general, anything below about 18 or 19, is a concern.

title: Drugs Affecting Bone Metabolism
content: High exposure to drugs that affect bone metabolism can impact health. The most common of these is corticosteroids, including systemic and inhaled corticosteroids. These can affect bone health in patients who have had significant asthma as children.

title: Smoking and Bone Density
content: Smoking is an independent risk factor for low BMD. Data shows that early smokers, defined as people who started smoking before the age of 16, have the worst bone density, followed by late smokers, with never smokers having the best bone density.

title: Drugs Negatively Impacting BMD
content: Corticosteroids, Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), and Antiepileptic drugs can negatively impact BMD. Corticosteroids impair the mineralization of bone and inhibit calcium absorption in the gut. PPIs interrupt intestinal calcium absorption, which then interrupts osteoclast formation and bone remodeling. Antiepileptic drugs, particularly phenytoin, can lead to increased catabolism of vitamin D, leading to decreased absorption of calcium in the gut.

title: Optimizing Bone Health in Children
content: During the ages of 8 to 20, it's important to ensure children are adequately nourished and very active, particularly in activities that load bones. It's also important to ensure BMI is not too low, hormone dysfunction is not present, energy availability is there, body fat is not too low, and that children are not smoking.

title: Physical Activity Impacting Bone Health
content: Resistance training and high force impact sports, such as football and MMA, are associated with the highest BMD values. Low weight bearing, low impact activities like walking, swimming and cycling, don't seem to improve BMD significantly. However, making these activities harder, such as walking with a rucksack and walking uphill, can apply more strain and potentially improve BMD.

title: Weight Loss Impact on Bone Health
content: Significant weight loss can lead to a decrease in BMD, particularly in the obese and elderly. However, the strategy for weight loss can impact the outcome. It's important to maintain a caloric deficit for weight loss, but the method of achieving this can vary.

title: Weight Loss and Bone Mineral Density
content: People who lose weight purely through nutritional manipulations tend to lose bone mineral density. However, those who combine weight loss with significant exercise tend to gain bone mineral density. The reduction in bone mineral density due to weight loss may be caused less by the mechanical loading of bones and more by a change in adipose derived factors like leptin and adiponectin and other hormones that move around when weight loss changes. Exercise is an important tool in a weight loss strategy as it can minimize the bone mineral density loss that is almost inevitable with weight loss.

title: Nutrition and Supplements for Bone Health
content: Essential nutrients for optimizing bone deposition include Calcium, Vitamin D (D3 specifically), and magnesium. Required daily amounts are Calcium, about 1000 to 1200 milligrams daily; Vitamin D, 800 to 1000 IU daily; Magnesium, 300 to 500 milligrams daily. These can be supplemented if you can’t get this sufficiently in food or through sunlight in the case of vitamin D. Calcium carbonate and calcium citrate are reasonable options for supplementing calcium. On the magnesium side, magnesium citrate, glycinate, and oxide are fantastic if you’re looking for a little speed up of the bowel. If you aren’t, you want magnesium carbonate.

title: Pharmaceutical Drugs for Low Bone Mineral Density
content: Pharmaceutical drugs are typically the last line of defense for those with low bone mineral density. There are three big classes of drugs: Bisphosphonates, monoclonal antibodies, and synthetic parathyroid hormone. Bisphosphonates strengthen bones by slowing the rate at which the osteoclasts remove bone. They increase bone mineral density by about four to 6% in the critical areas that matter, the femoral, neck, the hip, the lumbar spine, and they reduce the risk of fractures.

title: Impact of Extreme Sedentary Periods on Bone Health
content: Disuse osteopenia occurs when bones are chronically unloaded, leading to a very unfavorable combination of high bone resorption and low bone formation. This is relevant in cases of bedrest, paralysis based injuries or immobilization with injury. Bone density decreases by about 2% each month through microgravity, partial paralysis, and in the most extreme setting with complete paralysis, it can be up to 7% per month. For people experiencing this type of immobility, any form of physical therapy that can actively load muscles is beneficial. Cyclic blood flow restriction training (BFR) is also beneficial.
